statements.name: PROC PROTO
statements.description: Register, in batch mode, external functions that are written in the C or C++ programming languages.

arguments.name: PACKAGE=
arguments.description: specifies the SAS entry where the prototype information is saved. Entry is a three-level name having the following form: library.dataset.package. Package enables you to specify grouping in the GUI.

arguments.name: function-prototype-1
arguments.description: contains the C code of the function prototypes.

arguments.name: function-prototype-n
arguments.description: contains the C code of the function prototypes.

arguments.name: ENCRYPT
arguments.description: for XML databases only, enables the code to be encoded within a data set.

arguments.name: HIDE
arguments.description: for XML databases only, enables the code to be encoded within a data set.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a text string to describe or label a package.

arguments.name: NOSIGNALS
arguments.description: specifies that none of the functions in a package will produce exceptions.

arguments.name: STDCALL
arguments.description: for Windows PC platforms only, indicates that functions be called using the "_ stdcall" convention.

arguments.name: STRUCTPACK
arguments.description: for 32 bit Windows PC platforms or Power Architecture platform running on Linux only, specifies that all structures in a package be compiled with a specific N-BYTE packing pragma.

statements.name: LINK
statements.description: Specifies the name of the load module that contains your functions. Specifying the path is optional.

arguments.name: load-module
arguments.description: specifies the load module that contains your functions. You can add more LINK statements to include as many libraries as you need for your prototypes. Load-module can have the following forms, depending on your operating environment:

arguments.name: NOUNLOAD
arguments.description: specifies that selected libraries remain loaded when the SAS session ends.

statements.name: MAPMISS
statements.description: Specifies alternative values, by type, to pass to functions if values are missing.

arguments.name: POINTER=
arguments.description: specifies to pass NULL pointers to functions for missing numeric values.

arguments.name: CHARPOINTER=
arguments.description: specifies to pass NULL pointers to functions for missing character values

arguments.name: INT=
arguments.description: specifies an integer value to pass to functions for integer values that are missing.

arguments.name: DOUBLE=
arguments.description: specifies a double value to pass to functions for double values that are missing.

arguments.name: LONG=
arguments.description: specifies a long value to pass to functions for long values that are missing.

arguments.name: SHORT=
arguments.description: specifies a short value to pass to functions for short values that are missing.

statements.name: FUNCTION-PROTOTYPE-N
statements.description: Registers function prototypes in the PROTO procedure.

arguments.name: return-type
arguments.description: specifies a C language type for the returned value.

arguments.name: function-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the function to be registered.

arguments.name: argument-type
arguments.description: specifies the C language type for the function argument.

arguments.name: argument-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the argument.

arguments.name: iotype
arguments.description: specifies the I/O type of the argument. Use I for input, O for output, and U for update.

arguments.name: argument-label
arguments.description: specifies a description or label for the argument.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a description or a label for the function. Enclose the text string in quotation marks.

arguments.name: KIND
arguments.description: specifies the group that the function belongs to. The KIND= or GROUP= option allows for convenient grouping of functions in a package.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: specifies the group that the function belongs to. The KIND= or GROUP= option allows for convenient grouping of functions in a package.
